docs.snippet: The vast majority of Division I universities are public but the National Labor Relations Board has no power over them, only over private-sector employers like Northwestern....
docs.lead_paragraph: The vast majority of Division I universities are public but the National Labor Relations Board has no power over them, only over private-sector employers like Northwestern.
docs.abstract: Ruling by National Labor Relations Board that Northwestern’s scholarship football players could unionize leaves unanswered the question of what it means for nation's public universities' scholarship athletes; NLRB has no power over public universities, only over private-sector employers like Northwestern, meaning whether football or basketball players at a public university can unionize is up to its state government.

headline.main: Union Effort at Northwestern May Not Mean Much for Public Colleges
headline.print_headline: Union Effort at Northwestern May Not Mean Much for Public Colleges

docs.snippet: The young man, who is accused of killing a classmate at a high school on the morning of the junior prom, is being held at a medical facility under psychiatric evaluation, his lawyer said....
docs.lead_paragraph: The young man, who is accused of killing a classmate at a high school on the morning of the junior prom, is being held at a medical facility under psychiatric evaluation, his lawyer said.
docs.abstract: Students and faculty at Jonathan Law High School in Milford, Conn, are struggling to make sense of incident in which junior Chris Plaskon fatally stabbed classmate Maren Sanchez; both students are described as being popular; some speculate as to whether Sanchez's rejection of Plaskon's invitation to the prom was involved.

headline.main: Suspect in Stabbing at Connecticut School Is Described as Popular
headline.print_headline: Suspect in Stabbing at Connecticut School Is Described as Popular

byline.contributor: Nate Schweber reported from Milford, Conn., and Michael Schwirtz from New York. Alison Leigh Cowan, Elizabeth Maker, Daniel E. Slotnik and Vivian Yee contributed reporting.
byline.original: By NATE SCHWEBER and MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ

docs.snippet: Even with the team's "X-factor" suspended, the Washington Wizards had a No. 42 sitting next to the bench. The 57-year-old with graying hair couldn't box out or grab a rebound, but owner Ted Leonsis waved his red towel and egged on a cheering crowd...
docs.lead_paragraph: Even with the team's "X-factor" suspended, the Washington Wizards had a No. 42 sitting next to the bench. The 57-year-old with graying hair couldn't box out or grab a rebound, but owner Ted Leonsis waved his red towel and egged on a cheering crowd that chanted "Free Nene!"

headline.main: Wizards Beat Bulls 98-89, Take 3-1 Series Lead
